intro: Dimeria dipteros, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a succulent plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Aizoaceae, commonly referred to as the ice plant family, and is characterized by its fleshy, blue-green leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant has a compact, cushion-like growth habit, which helps it conserve water in its harsh environment. Its flowers are typically short-lived, opening in the morning and closing by midday, a trait common in many desert flora. Dimeria dipteros is well adapted to extreme heat and drought, with thick, waxy leaves that reduce water loss through transpiration.
